item.title: Chapter 1
item.description: Introduction and Overview Exercise 1.1 So long as the set of possible \(x\) is finite, only 2 times are needed to keep error probability less than 1/2. Say \(x_0\neq x_1\in {0,…,2^{n}-1}\), $$ f(x_0)=f(x_1) \Rightarrow f\ \text{is constant,}\\ f(x_0)\ne f(x_1) \Rightarrow f\ \text{is balanced.} $$ For the second condition, no error will occur. For the first condition, error occurs when we pick two variable from the same subset with \(2^n-1\) members, so the error probabilty is $$ \epsilon=\dfrac{2^{n-1}-1}{2^n-1}=\dfrac{1}{2}-\dfrac{1}{2(2^n-1)}<\dfrac{1}{2}.
